question: Should the development of genetically modified organisms be banned?

content.source_1: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (2016). Genetically Engineered Crops: Experiences and Prospects. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. Conclusion: No substantiated evidence that currently commercialized GE foods are less safe to eat than non-GE foods; human health risks appear comparable to conventional crops. Implication: Weighs against a blanket ban on development. https://nap.edu/23395
content.source_2: Benbrook, C. (2012). Impacts of genetically engineered crops on pesticide use in the U.S. — the first sixteen years. Environmental Sciences Europe, 24:24. Finding: Herbicide use increased substantially over time, largely due to the emergence of glyphosate-resistant weeds, raising environmental and resistance-management concerns. Implication: Supports arguments for strong restrictions or a ban. https://doi.org/10.1186/2190-4715-24-24
content.source_3: Klümper, W., & Qaim, M. (2014). A Meta-Analysis of the Impacts of Genetically Modified Crops. PLOS ONE, 9(11): e111629. Finding: Across 147 studies, GM crops increased yields and farmer profits on average, offering economic and food security benefits, especially for smallholders in developing countries. Implication: Weighs against a blanket ban due to demonstrated socioeconomic gains. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0111629
content.source_4: Bowman v. Monsanto Co., 569 U.S. 278 (2013). U.S. Supreme Court decision holding that patent exhaustion does not permit farmers to reproduce patented seeds without authorization. Finding: Reinforces strong corporate IP control over seeds, raising concerns about farmer autonomy, dependency, and equity. Implication: Cited by critics to justify bans or moratoria on GMO development tied to restrictive seed regimes. https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/569/278/
content.source_5: Tang, G., et al. (2012). Golden Rice is an effective source of vitamin A. The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, 96(3): 658–664. Finding: Beta-carotene in Golden Rice effectively converts to vitamin A in humans, indicating potential to reduce vitamin A deficiency in vulnerable populations. Implication: Humanitarian and public-health benefits argue against a categorical ban. https://doi.org/10.3945/ajcn.111.030775
content.source_6: Snow, A. A., Andow, D. A., Gepts, P., et al. (2005). Genetically engineered organisms and the environment: current status and recommendations. Ecological Applications, 15(2): 377–404. Finding: Identifies ecological risks such as transgene flow to wild relatives, potential non-target effects, and resistance evolution; recommends robust, case-by-case ecological risk assessment and monitoring. Implication: Supports precautionary approaches and is used to argue for moratoria or strict limits; some extend this to calls for bans. https://doi.org/10.1890/04-0921
